factoid: Gabriel informed Máryá Dmítrievna that the men who had come had run away again.
Máryá Dmítrievna rose frowning.
Máryá Dmítrievna clasped her hands behind her.
Máryá Dmítrievna paced through the rooms for a long time.
Máryá Dmítrievna considered what she should do.
Toward midnight, Máryá Dmítrievna went to Natásha’s room.
Máryá Dmítrievna was fingering the key in her pocket.
Sónya was sitting sobbing in the corridor.
Sónya pleaded with Máryá Dmítrievna to let her in to Natásha.
Máryá Dmítrievna unlocked the door to Natásha’s room.
Máryá Dmítrievna entered Natásha’s room without giving an answer.
Máryá Dmítrievna thought that the situation was disgusting, abominable, and that Natásha was a horrid girl and hussy.
Máryá Dmítrievna decided to tell everyone to hold their tongues and hide the matter from the count.
Máryá Dmítrievna entered the room with resolute steps.
Natásha was lying on the sofa with her head hidden in her hands and did not stir.
Natásha was in the same position as when Máryá Dmítrievna had left her.
Máryá Dmítrievna said that Natásha was a nice girl.
Máryá Dmítrievna accused Natásha of arranging meetings with lovers in her house.
Máryá Dmítrievna touched Natásha’s arm.
Máryá Dmítrievna told Natásha to listen when she spoke and accused her of disgracing herself like the lowest of hussies.
Máryá Dmítrievna said she would conceal the matter because she was sorry for Natásha’s father.
Natásha did not change her position but her body heaved with noiseless, convulsive sobs that choked her.
Máryá Dmítrievna glanced around at Sónya.
Máryá Dmítrievna seated herself on the sofa beside Natásha.
Máryá Dmítrievna said that it was lucky that Natásha’s father had escaped her but that she would find him.
Máryá Dmítrievna asked whether Natásha heard what she was saying.
Máryá Dmítrievna put her large hand under Natásha’s face and turned it toward her.
Both Máryá Dmítrievna and Sónya were amazed when they saw how Natásha looked.
Natásha’s eyes were dry and glistening.
Natásha’s lips were compressed.
Natásha’s cheeks were sunken.
Natásha muttered that she wanted to be left alone and that she would die.
Natásha wrenching herself from Máryá Dmítrievna’s hands with a vicious effort and sinking down again into her former position.
Máryá Dmítrievna said that she wished for Natásha’s good, that Natásha lie still, and that she would not touch her.
Máryá Dmítrievna said she would not tell Natásha how guilty she was but would not reveal it to Natásha’s father.
Natásha’s body shook with sobs.
Natásha said that if Natásha’s father found out, her brother, and her betrothed would be involved.
Natásha said she had no betrothed because she had refused him.
Máryá Dmítrievna said that it was all the same.
Máryá Dmítrievna asked whether they would let the matter pass if they heard of it and whether Natásha’s father could challenge him to a duel.
Natásha shouted that she wanted to be left alone and asked why Máryá Dmítrievna had interfered.
Natásha raised herself on the sofa and looked malignantly at Máryá Dmítrievna.
Máryá Dmítrievna asked what Natásha wanted and grew angry again.
Natásha asked whether Máryá Dmítrievna had been kept under lock and key and who hindered Natásha’s father’s coming to the house.
Natásha questioned why she was carried off as if she were a gypsy singing girl.
Natásha wondered if Natásha’s father, brother, or betrothed would not have found the father if he had carried her off.
Natásha called Natásha’s father a scoundrel and a wretch.
Natásha exclaimed that Natásha’s father was better than any of them.
Natásha got up.
Natásha said that if Máryá Dmítrievna had not interfered she would be fine but she was upset and asked Sónya to go away.
Natásha burst into sobs with despairing vehemence.
Máryá Dmítrievna was about to speak again but Natásha cried out that she was hated and despised and threw herself back on the sofa.
Natásha threw herself back on the sofa.
